Award.AwardTitle: Quantifying the Relative Roles of Progressive Land Use Change, Irrigation, and Remote Forcing in Southern Great Plains Precipitation Variability
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to understand the causes of precipitation variability in the US Southern Great Plains (SGP), roughly equivalent to the region covered by Nebraska, Missouri, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Texas, and Louisiana. This area is among the most drought-prone in the US, with substantial economic impacts including the severe consequences of the Dust Bowl and losses in the tens of billions of dollars in 2011 and 2012. Precipitation anomalies in the region, including rainfall deficits contributing to droughts, are generally attributed to changes in the large-scale atmospheric circulation brought about by fluctuations in sea surface temperature (SST). But local land surface conditions can act to intensify remotely-forced precipitation variability through several mechanisms. For instance, lack of rainfall leads to dry soil and reduced evaporation, which reduces the moisture source available for precipitation and causes further rainfall reduction. Also, warm dry conditions due to drought promote ridging in the mid-troposphere, which can further reduce precipitation as rain-bearing systems move around the ridge.

This project considers the extent to which the strength of such land surface feedbacks to precipitation has changed due to changes in land use and land cover change in the SGP. Since the 1950s much of the native vegetation in the region has been replaced by agricultural crops, and this substitution can affect the exchange of water between the surface and the overlying atmosphere. Native plants have much deeper roots and can access soil moisture from reserves unavailable to crops, thereby maintaining the source of moisture for precipitation even during dry spells. Also, crops tend to green up earlier than native plants, so that plant uptake and transpiration of soil moisture begins earlier on agricultural land. The enhanced early season moisture demand could increase drought susceptibility later in the growing season. A further consideration is the widespread adoption of irrigation, which can increase evaporation and transpiration during wet years but is not reliable during exceptional drought years.

The research is conducted through a suite of simulations performed using the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model, a regional model which is configured with high resolution over the great plains. WRF is coupled to the Community Land Model (CLM), in which land cover can be specified to represent past and present vegetation cover and varying levels of irrigation can be represented. Experiments consist largely of WRF-CLM simulations over the period of the North American Regional Reanalysis (NARR, 1979-2012), first with land cover held fixed to the modern land cover attributes (from the National Land Cover Database). This simulation is then compared with additional simulations in which land cover is configured to represent conditions during the pre-settlement era (based on data representing the year 1850), intermediate land use conditions around 1920, and the dust bowl. Simulations for modern and intermediate land use are performed with and without irrigation.

The work has societal broader impacts due to the economic and societal impact of drought in the SGP. The findings of the research may be useful to the agricultural sector and SGP water managers as they make decisions regarding changes in land and water use in the region. In addition to publications in peer-reviewed research journals, results of the research will be distributed through the University of Nebraska-Lincoln Extension and other extension services across the SGP. In addition the project will support and train two graduate student, thereby providing for the future workforce in this research area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project entitled “Quantifying the Relative Roles of Progressive Land Use Change, Irrigation, and Remote Forcing in Southern Great Plains Precipitation Variability” (federal award 1355916) was active from July 2014-June 2018.  Key outcomes and findings of this project include:

(i) The value of several common land surface models (LSMs) has been tested over the Southern Great Plains region of the United States, and recommendations have been made about which LSM to use for particular research applications.  Choosing the optimal LSM ensures a good representation of temperature and precipitation patterns for this region, and may be helpful to optimize computing resources. 

(ii) Polarimetric radar observations have been related to wintertime precipitation rate in a Southern Great Plains winter storm.  This work improves interpretation of radar data by allowing forecasters to estimate an approximate precipitation rate in sleet, snow, and freezing rain.  Prior, it was less certain how to estimate wintertime precipitation rate, particularly in snow and sleet.   

(iii) A mechanism has been identified to explain the initiation and maintenance of the Dust Bowl drought on the United States Southern Great Plains.  Leading up to the Dust Bowl drought, land cover changed from primarily native grassland into dry cropland.  This land cover change resulted in increased surface reflectance.  As less energy was absorbed at the surface, the surface cooled, resulting in anomalous sinking motion over the Great Plains and anomalous northerly flow away from the region of sinking motion.  This reduced the northward flow of moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, reducing precipitation.  The simulated precipitation deficit with Dust Bowl land cover was in reasonable agreement with observed precipitation deficits during the Dust Bowl. 

(iv) Precipitation anomalies in the Southern Great Plains region are also influenced substantially by oceanic temperature anomalies.  This remote forcing effect may be responsible for some of the decadal variability in Southern Great Plains precipitation, since oceanic remote forcing may be decadal in timescale.  Influence of remote forcing may, however, vary as a function of initial soil condition (whether moist or dry) and land cover condition.  Effects of the Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation (AMO) were tested under several land cover scenarios and with initially moist or dry soil in the Southern Plains region.  When Dust Bowl land cover was used, the AMO strongly influenced Southern Plains precipitation outcomes, while other land cover scenarios did not allow the AMO to have as substantial an effect on regional precipitation.  Even if the soil started wet, both a warm-phase and cold-phase AMO could be associated with regional drought under Dust Bowl land cover.  This result points to the importance of land cover in determining regional precipitation anomalies. 

At the close of the project, the key findings have been reported in four peer-reviewed journal articles.  Five graduate students (1 Ph.D., 4 M.S.) have completed a degree related to this project and are now part of the STEM workforce or are continuing their education. 

The key outcomes and findings of this project help us understand Southern Plains drought and the response of regional precipitation patterns to altered land use, and therefore are of interest to American taxpayers.  The region is important for agriculture, livestock, and the health of several natural ecosystems.  The findings of this project may enable future policy decisions to optimize regional land use in a way that minimizes the probability of future catastrophic drought.  There is also now a stronger basis on which to make predictions of future precipitation patterns for this region given particular land use scenarios, which may allow better resiliency via the ability to prepare for expected impacts of altered future precipitation.
